lessonOverview.title: Unit 5 - Lesson 2
structures: A: What does he/she look like?

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and name eight facial and hair descriptions (short hair, long hair, curly hair, straight hair, a beard, big eyes, freckles, a round face) when listening and looking at visual prompts.
supportStrategies: (Vocab) Use SB visuals. Say: “Who’s got curly hair?” Students point or circle the correct face. Review new terms with actions (e.g., pretend to curl hair).

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can ask and answer simple questions about appearance using “What does he/she look like?” and respond with “He’s/She’s got...”.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Do “Guess Who?” pair game: one student describes, the other guesses: “She’s got big eyes and freckles.” “It’s number 3!”

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can use the target structure “What does he/she look like?” / “He’s/She’s got ___.” to describe people’s appearance.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write Q&A: “What does she look like?” → “She’s got short hair.” Do a chain drill where students describe someone and the class guesses.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
